choice_explanation: Coca earns $400-600/month vs coffee's $150-200. About 60% of farmers in these regions grow coca.
tooltip_info: Cultivation linked to production: 8-15 years (Peru Article 296)

choice_explanation: Coffee farming provides legal stability but means living below poverty line at ~$150-200/month.
tooltip_info: Legal but economically difficult - many switch to coca within 3-5 years

choice_explanation: About 75% of coca farmers sell to intermediaries without processing involvement.
tooltip_info: Selling coca for cocaine production = 8-15 years minimum (Peru Article 296)

choice_text: Get ENACO permits for legal coca
choice_explanation: ENACO holds state monopoly on legal coca. Permits are difficult to obtain and pay below market rates.
tooltip_info: Legal coca is possible but restricted. Bolivia allows 22,000 hectares; Peru's system is more limited.

choice_text: Report the cocaine lab to authorities
choice_explanation: Cooperation with authorities is rare - under 15% of farmers report suspicious activity.
tooltip_info: Witness protection exists but rural reintegration is difficult. Informants face retaliation risk.

choice_text: Hide your crop and hope they miss it
choice_explanation: Some farmers attempt concealment. Detection methods include aerial surveillance and local intelligence.
tooltip_info: Hiding illegal crops is common but risky. Detection often leads to criminal charges.

choice_explanation: Many farmers accept eradication to avoid confrontation, then relocate cultivation to remote areas.
tooltip_info: Forced eradication without alternatives often leads to relocation of cultivation rather than cessation.

choice_explanation: Armed resistance occurs in some regions. Confrontations have resulted in deaths on both sides.
tooltip_info: Resistance can lead to terrorism charges. 47 deaths in Peru 2010-2020, 13 in Colombia 2019-2022.

choice_text: Take a loan from the local merchant
choice_explanation: Informal lending is the only credit available for most rural farmers. Interest rates are high.
tooltip_info: Informal loans often have 10-20% monthly interest. Collateral is typically land.

choice_text: Join a cooperative with other farmers
choice_explanation: Cooperatives provide collective bargaining and reduce dependence on intermediaries.
tooltip_info: About 30% of cooperatives succeed long-term. Success correlates with external support and market access.

choice_explanation: About 25% of farmers in coca-growing regions eventually migrate to urban areas.
tooltip_info: Migration driven by agricultural unprofitability. Urban informal work offers different but persistent poverty.

choice_text: Switch to coca to pay off the debt
choice_explanation: Studies show ~55% of indebted farmers switch to coca within 3 years.
tooltip_info: Debt is a primary driver of coca cultivation. Creates cycle between creditors and enforcement.

choice_text: Default on the loan and lose your land
choice_explanation: Land seizure through debt is common. Former farmland is often used for coca by new owners.
tooltip_info: Informal lending lacks legal protection for borrowers. Debt default usually means losing land.

choice_explanation: Programs provide $1,000-2,000 over 2 years. Alternative crops take 3-5 years to produce.
tooltip_info: Payment delays are common (6-12 months). Only 30% remain in legal crops after 5 years.
